au_430957: for i in /opt/metasploit-framework/*msf; do ln -s "$i" /usr/local/bin/; done

ls -1 /opt/metasploit-framework/*msf | while IFS= read -r msf; do 
    ln -s /opt/metasploit-framework/"$i" /usr/local/bin/; done

Explanations about Options.-s: make symbolic links instead of hard links

Top-3 Scripts:
so_49313434: gcc -v -c hello.c

gcc -v -o Cuteee main.o -L. -lhello

so_12235622: gcc myotherprogram.c -o myotherprogram -L/some/path -lxyz

gcc myotherprogram.c -o myotherprogram -L/some/path -lxyz -lm

Explanations about Options.-x:
Turn off any specification of a language, so that subsequent files are handled
 according to their file name suffixes (as they are if -x has not been used at all).
Explanations about Options.-v:
Print (on standard error output) the commands executed to run the stages of
 compilation. Also print the version number of the compiler driver program and of the
 preprocessor and the compiler proper.
Explanations about Options.-o:
Place output in file file. This applies to whatever sort of output is being produced,
 whether it be an executable file, an object file, an assembler file or preprocessed C
 code.
Explanations about Options.-l:
Search the library named library when linking. (The second alternative with the
 library as a separate argument is only for POSIX compliance and is not recommended.)
Explanations about Options.-z: in the documentation of your linker for permitted values and their meanings.
Explanations about Options.-e:
Specify that the program entry point is entry. The argument is interpreted by the
 linker; the GNU linker accepts either a symbol name or an address.

Top-3 Similar Questions: so_49313434: Fail to create an executable file linking a static library

Explanations about Options.-o:
Use output as the name for the program produced by ld; if this option is not
 specified, the name a.out is used by default. The script command "OUTPUT" can also
 specify the output file name.
Explanations about Options.-m:
Emulate the emulation linker. You can list the available emulations with the
 --verbose or -V options.
Explanations about Options.-l:
Add the archive or object file specified by namespec to the list of files to link.
 This option may be used any number of times. If namespec is of the form :filename, ld
 will search the library path for a file called filename, otherwise it will search the
 library path for a file called libnamespec.a.
Explanations about Options.-h:
When creating an ELF shared object, set the internal DT_SONAME field to the specified
 name. When an executable is linked with a shared object which has a DT_SONAME field,
 then when the executable is run the dynamic linker will attempt to load the shared
 object specified by the DT_SONAME field rather than the using the file name given to
 the linker.
Explanations about Options.-e:
Use entry as the explicit symbol for beginning execution of your program, rather than
 the default entry point. If there is no symbol named entry, the linker will try to
 parse entry as a number, and use that as the entry address (the number will be
 interpreted in base 10; you may use a leading 0x for base 16, or a leading 0 for base
 8).
Explanations about Options.-y:
Print the name of each linked file in which symbol appears. This option may be given
 any number of times. On many systems it is necessary to prepend an underscore.
